Distributions Provided by mniw

Martin Lysy

2024-09-19

mniw-distributions.Rmd

Wishart Distribution

The Wishart distribution on a random positive-definite matrix ğ—qÃ—q{\boldsymbol{X}}_{q\times q} is is denoted ğ—âˆ¼Wish(ğš¿,Î½){\boldsymbol{X}}\sim \textrm{Wish}({\boldsymbol{\Psi}}, \nu), and defined as ğ—=(ğ‹ğ™)(ğ‹ğ™)â€²{\boldsymbol{X}}= ({\boldsymbol{L}}{\boldsymbol{Z}})({\boldsymbol{L}}{\boldsymbol{Z}})', where:

  • ğš¿qÃ—q=ğ‹ğ‹â€²{\boldsymbol{\Psi}}_{q\times q} = {\boldsymbol{L}}{\boldsymbol{L}}' is the positive-definite matrix scale parameter,

  • Î½>q\nu > q is the shape parameter,

  • ğ™qÃ—q{\boldsymbol{Z}}_{q\times q} is a random lower-triangular matrix with elements

    Zij{âˆ¼iidğ’©(0,1)i<jâˆ¼indÏ‡(Î½âˆ’i+1)2i=j=0i>j. Z_{ij} \begin{cases} \overset{\;\textrm{iid}\;}{\sim}\mathcal{N}(0,1) & i < j \\ \overset{\:\textrm{ind}\:}{\sim}\chi^2_{(\nu-i+1)} & i = j \\ = 0 & i > j. \end{cases}

The log-density of the Wishart distribution is

logp(ğ—âˆ£ğš¿,Î½)=âˆ’12[tr(ğš¿âˆ’1ğ—)+(q+1âˆ’Î½)log|ğ—|+Î½log|ğš¿|+Î½qlog(2)+2logÎ“q(Î½2)], \log p({\boldsymbol{X}}\mid {\boldsymbol{\Psi}}, \nu) = -\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}} \left[\mathrm{tr}({\boldsymbol{\Psi}}^{-1} {\boldsymbol{X}}) + (q+1-\nu)\log |{\boldsymbol{X}}| + \nu \log |{\boldsymbol{\Psi}}| + \nu q \log(2) + 2 \log \Gamma_q(\textstyle{\frac{\nu }{2}})\right],

where Î“n(x)\Gamma_n(x) is the multivariate Gamma function defined as

Î“n(x)=Ï€n(nâˆ’1)/4âˆj=1nÎ“(x+12(1âˆ’j)). \Gamma_n(x) = \pi^{n(n-1)/4} \prod_{j=1}^n \Gamma\big(x + \textstyle{\frac{1}{2}} (1-j)\big).

Inverse-Wishart Distribution

The Inverse-Wishart distribution ğ—âˆ¼InvWish(ğš¿,Î½){\boldsymbol{X}}\sim \textrm{InvWish}({\boldsymbol{\Psi}}, \nu) is defined as ğ—âˆ’1âˆ¼Wish(ğš¿âˆ’1,Î½){\boldsymbol{X}}^{-1} \sim \textrm{Wish}({\boldsymbol{\Psi}}^{-1}, \nu). Its log-density is given by

logp(ğ—âˆ£ğš¿,Î½)=âˆ’12[tr(ğš¿ğ—âˆ’1)+(Î½+q+1)log|ğ—|âˆ’Î½log|ğš¿|+Î½qlog(2)+2logÎ“q(Î½2)]. \log p({\boldsymbol{X}}\mid {\boldsymbol{\Psi}}, \nu) = -\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}} \left[\mathrm{tr}({\boldsymbol{\Psi}}{\boldsymbol{X}}^{-1}) + (\nu+q+1) \log |{\boldsymbol{X}}| - \nu \log |{\boldsymbol{\Psi}}| + \nu q \log(2) + 2 \log \Gamma_q(\textstyle{\frac{\nu }{2}})\right].

Properties

If ğ—qÃ—qâˆ¼Wish(ğš¿,Î½){\boldsymbol{X}}_{q\times q} \sim \textrm{Wish}({\boldsymbol{\Psi}},\nu), the for a nonzero vector ğšâˆˆâ„q{\boldsymbol{a}}\in \mathbb R^q we have

ğšâ€²ğ—ğšğšâ€²ğš¿ğšâˆ¼Ï‡(Î½)2. \frac{{\boldsymbol{a}}'{\boldsymbol{X}}{\boldsymbol{a}}}{{\boldsymbol{a}}'{\boldsymbol{\Psi}}{\boldsymbol{a}}} \sim \chi^2_{(\nu)}.

Matrix-Normal Distribution

The Matrix-Normal distribution on a random matrix ğ—pÃ—q{\boldsymbol{X}}_{p \times q} is denoted ğ—âˆ¼MatNorm(ğš²,ğšºR,ğšºC){\boldsymbol{X}}\sim \textrm{MatNorm}({\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_R, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_C), and defined as ğ—=ğ‹ğ™ğ”+ğš²{\boldsymbol{X}}= {\boldsymbol{L}}{\boldsymbol{Z}}{\boldsymbol{U}}+ {\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}, where:

  • ğš²pÃ—q{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}_{p \times q} is the mean matrix parameter,
  • ğšºRpÃ—p=ğ‹ğ‹â€²{{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_R}_{p \times p} = {\boldsymbol{L}}{\boldsymbol{L}}' is the row-variance matrix parameter,
  • ğšºCqÃ—q=ğ”â€²ğ”{{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_C}_{q \times q} = {\boldsymbol{U}}'{\boldsymbol{U}} is the column-variance matrix parameter,
  • ğ™qÃ—q{\boldsymbol{Z}}_{q\times q} is a random matrix with Zijâˆ¼iidğ’©(0,1)Z_{ij} \overset{\;\textrm{iid}\;}{\sim}\mathcal{N}(0,1).

The log-density of the Matrix-Normal distribution is

logp(ğ—âˆ£ğš²,ğšºR,ğšºC)=âˆ’12[tr(ğšºCâˆ’1(ğ—âˆ’ğš²)â€²ğšºRâˆ’1(ğ—âˆ’ğš²))+Î½qlog(2Ï€)+Î½log|ğšºC|+qlog|ğšºR|]. \log p({\boldsymbol{X}}\mid {\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_R, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_C) = -\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}} \left[\mathrm{tr}\big({\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_C^{-1}({\boldsymbol{X}}-{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}})'{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_R^{-1}({\boldsymbol{X}}-{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}})\big) + \nu q \log(2\pi) + \nu \log |{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_C| + q \log |{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_R|\right].

Properties

If ğ—pÃ—qâˆ¼MatNorm(ğš²,ğšºR,ğšºC){\boldsymbol{X}}_{p \times q} \sim \textrm{MatNorm}({\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_R, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_C), then for nonzero vectors ğšâˆˆâ„p{\boldsymbol{a}}\in \mathbb R^p and ğ›âˆˆâ„q{\boldsymbol{b}}\in \mathbb R^q we have

ğšâ€²ğ—ğ›âˆ¼ğ’©(ğšâ€²ğš²ğ›,ğšâ€²ğšºRğšâ‹…ğ›â€²ğšºCğ›). {\boldsymbol{a}}' {\boldsymbol{X}}{\boldsymbol{b}}\sim \mathcal{N}({\boldsymbol{a}}' {\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}{\boldsymbol{b}}, {\boldsymbol{a}}'{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_R{\boldsymbol{a}}\cdot {\boldsymbol{b}}'{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_C{\boldsymbol{b}}).

Matrix-Normal Inverse-Wishart Distribution

The Matrix-Normal Inverse-Wishart Distribution on a random matrix ğ—pÃ—q{\boldsymbol{X}}_{p \times q} and random positive-definite matrix ğ•qÃ—q{\boldsymbol{V}}_{q\times q} is denoted (ğ—,ğ•)âˆ¼MNIW(ğš²,ğšº,ğš¿,Î½)({\boldsymbol{X}},{\boldsymbol{V}}) \sim \textrm{MNIW}({\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}, {\boldsymbol{\Psi}}, \nu), and defined as

ğ—âˆ£ğ•âˆ¼MatNorm(ğš²,ğšº,ğ•)ğ•âˆ¼InvWish(ğš¿,Î½). \begin{aligned} {\boldsymbol{X}}\mid {\boldsymbol{V}}& \sim \textrm{MatNorm}({\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}, {\boldsymbol{V}}) \\ {\boldsymbol{V}}& \sim \textrm{InvWish}({\boldsymbol{\Psi}}, \nu). \end{aligned}

Properties

The MNIX distribution is conjugate prior for the multivariable response regression model

ğ˜nÃ—qâˆ¼MatNorm(ğ—nÃ—pğ›ƒpÃ—q,ğ•,ğšº). {\boldsymbol{Y}}_{n \times q} \sim \textrm{MatNorm}({\boldsymbol{X}}_{n\times p} {\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{p \times q}, {\boldsymbol{V}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}).

That is, if (ğ›ƒ,ğšº)âˆ¼MNIW(ğš²,ğ›€âˆ’1,ğš¿,Î½)({\boldsymbol{\beta}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}) \sim \textrm{MNIW}({\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}, {\boldsymbol{\Omega}}^{-1}, {\boldsymbol{\Psi}}, \nu), then

ğ›ƒ,ğšºâˆ£ğ˜âˆ¼MNIW(ğš²Ì‚,ğ›€Ì‚âˆ’1,ğš¿Ì‚,Î½Ì‚), {\boldsymbol{\beta}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}\mid {\boldsymbol{Y}}\sim \textrm{MNIW}(\hat {\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}, \hat {\boldsymbol{\Omega}}^{-1}, \hat {\boldsymbol{\Psi}}, \hat \nu),

where

ğ›€Ì‚=ğ—â€²ğ•âˆ’1ğ—+ğ›€ğš¿Ì‚=ğš¿+ğ˜â€²ğ•âˆ’1ğ˜+ğš²â€²ğ›€ğš²âˆ’ğš²Ì‚â€²ğ›€Ì‚ğš²Ì‚ğš²Ì‚=ğ›€Ì‚âˆ’1(ğ—â€²ğ•âˆ’1ğ˜+ğ›€ğš²)Î½Ì‚=Î½+n. \begin{aligned} \hat {\boldsymbol{\Omega}}& = {\boldsymbol{X}}'{\boldsymbol{V}}^{-1}{\boldsymbol{X}}+ {\boldsymbol{\Omega}} & \hat {\boldsymbol{\Psi}}& = {\boldsymbol{\Psi}}+ {\boldsymbol{Y}}'{\boldsymbol{V}}^{-1}{\boldsymbol{Y}}+ {\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}'{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}- \hat {\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}'\hat {\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\hat {\boldsymbol{\Lambda}} \\ \hat {\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}& = \hat {\boldsymbol{\Omega}}^{-1}({\boldsymbol{X}}'{\boldsymbol{V}}^{-1}{\boldsymbol{Y}}+ {\boldsymbol{\Omega}}{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}) & \hat \nu & = \nu + n. \end{aligned}

Matrix-t Distribution

The Matrix-tt distribution on a random matrix ğ—pÃ—q{\boldsymbol{X}}_{p \times q} is denoted ğ—âˆ¼MatT(ğš²,ğšºR,ğšºC,Î½){\boldsymbol{X}}\sim \textrm{MatT}({\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_R, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_C, \nu), and defined as the marginal distribution of ğ—{\boldsymbol{X}} for (ğ—,ğ•)âˆ¼MNIW(ğš²,ğšºR,ğšºC,Î½)({\boldsymbol{X}}, {\boldsymbol{V}}) \sim \textrm{MNIW}({\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_R, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_C, \nu). Its log-density is given by

logp(ğ—âˆ£ğš²,ğšºR,ğšºC,Î½)=âˆ’12[(Î½+p+qâˆ’1)log|I+ğšºRâˆ’1(ğ—âˆ’ğš²)ğšºCâˆ’1(ğ—âˆ’ğš²)â€²|=âˆ’12[+qlog|ğšºR|+plog|ğšºC|=âˆ’12[+pqlog(Ï€)âˆ’logÎ“q(Î½+p+qâˆ’12)+logÎ“q(Î½+qâˆ’12)]. \begin{aligned} \log p({\boldsymbol{X}}\mid {\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_R, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_C, \nu) & = -\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}} \Big[(\nu+p+q-1)\log | I + {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_R^{-1}({\boldsymbol{X}}-{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}){\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_C^{-1}({\boldsymbol{X}}-{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}})'| \\ & \phantom{= -\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}} \Big[} + q \log |{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_R| + p \log |{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_C| \\ & \phantom{= -\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}} \Big[} + pq \log(\pi) - \log \Gamma_q(\textstyle{\frac{\nu+p+q-1}{2}}) + \log \Gamma_q(\textstyle{\frac{\nu+q-1}{2}})\Big]. \end{aligned}

Properties

If ğ—pÃ—qâˆ¼MatT(ğš²,ğšºR,ğšºC,Î½){\boldsymbol{X}}_{p\times q} \sim \textrm{MatT}({\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_R, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_C, \nu), then for nonzero vectors ğšâˆˆâ„p{\boldsymbol{a}}\in \mathbb R^p and ğ›âˆˆâ„q{\boldsymbol{b}}\in \mathbb R^q we have

ğšâ€²ğ—ğ›âˆ’Î¼Ïƒâˆ¼t(Î½âˆ’q+1), \frac{{\boldsymbol{a}}'{\boldsymbol{X}}{\boldsymbol{b}}- \mu}{\sigma} \sim t_{(\nu -q + 1)},

where Î¼=ğšâ€²ğš²ğ›,Ïƒ2=ğšâ€²ğšºRğšâ‹…ğ›â€²ğšºCğ›Î½âˆ’q+1. \mu = {\boldsymbol{a}}'{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}{\boldsymbol{b}}, \qquad \sigma^2 = \frac{{\boldsymbol{a}}'{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_R{\boldsymbol{a}}\cdot {\boldsymbol{b}}'{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_C{\boldsymbol{b}}}{\nu - q + 1}.

Random-Effects Normal Distribution

Consider the multivariate normal distribution on qq-dimensional vectors ğ±{\boldsymbol{x}} and ğ›{\boldsymbol{\mu}} given by

ğ±âˆ£ğ›âˆ¼ğ’©(ğ›,ğ•)ğ›âˆ¼ğ’©(ğ›Œ,ğšº). \begin{aligned} {\boldsymbol{x}}\mid {\boldsymbol{\mu}}& \sim \mathcal{N}({\boldsymbol{\mu}}, {\boldsymbol{V}}) \\ {\boldsymbol{\mu}}& \sim \mathcal{N}({\boldsymbol{\lambda}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}). \end{aligned}

The random-effects normal distribution is defined as the posterior distribution ğ›âˆ¼p(ğ›âˆ£ğ±){\boldsymbol{\mu}}\sim p({\boldsymbol{\mu}}\mid {\boldsymbol{x}}), which is given by

ğ›âˆ£ğ±âˆ¼ğ’©(ğ†(ğ±âˆ’ğ›Œ)+ğ›Œ,ğ†ğ•),ğ†=ğšº(ğ•+ğšº)âˆ’1. {\boldsymbol{\mu}}\mid {\boldsymbol{x}}\sim \mathcal{N}\big({\boldsymbol{G}}({\boldsymbol{x}}-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}) + {\boldsymbol{\lambda}}, {\boldsymbol{G}}{\boldsymbol{V}}\big), \qquad {\boldsymbol{G}}= {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}({\boldsymbol{V}}+ {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}})^{-1}.

The notation for this distribution is ğ›âˆ¼RxNorm(ğ±,ğ•,ğ›Œ,ğšº){\boldsymbol{\mu}}\sim \textrm{RxNorm}({\boldsymbol{x}}, {\boldsymbol{V}}, {\boldsymbol{\lambda}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}).

Hierarchical Normal-Normal Model

The hierarchical Normal-Normal model is defined as

ğ²iâˆ£ğ›i,ğ›ƒ,ğšºâˆ¼indğ’©(ğ›i,ğ•i)ğ›iâˆ£ğ›ƒ,ğšºâˆ¼iidğ’©(ğ±iâ€²ğ›ƒ,ğšº)(ğ›ƒ,ğšº)âˆ¼MNIW(ğš²,ğ›€âˆ’1,ğš¿,Î½), \begin{aligned} {\boldsymbol{y}}_i \mid {\boldsymbol{\mu}}_i, {\boldsymbol{\beta}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}& \overset{\:\textrm{ind}\:}{\sim}\mathcal{N}({\boldsymbol{\mu}}_i, {\boldsymbol{V}}_i) \\ {\boldsymbol{\mu}}_i \mid {\boldsymbol{\beta}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}& \overset{\;\textrm{iid}\;}{\sim}\mathcal{N}({\boldsymbol{x}}_i'{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}) \\ ({\boldsymbol{\beta}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}) & \sim \textrm{MNIW}({\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}, {\boldsymbol{\Omega}}^{-1}, {\boldsymbol{\Psi}}, \nu), \end{aligned}

where:

  • ğ²iqÃ—1{{\boldsymbol{y}}_i}_{q\times 1} is the response vector for subject ii,
  • ğ›iqÃ—1{{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_i}_{q\times 1} is the random effect for subject ii,
  • ğ•iqÃ—q{{\boldsymbol{V}}_i}_{q\times q} is the error variance for subject ii,
  • ğ±ipÃ—1{{\boldsymbol{x}}_i}_{p\times 1} is the covariate vector for subject ii,
  • ğ›ƒpÃ—q{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{p \times q} is the random-effects coefficient matrix,
  • ğšºqÃ—q{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{q \times q} is the random-effects error variance.

Let ğ˜nÃ—q=(ğ²1,â€¦,ğ²n){\boldsymbol{Y}}_{n\times q} = ({\boldsymbol{y}}_{1},\ldots,{\boldsymbol{y}}_{n}), ğ—nÃ—p=(ğ±1,â€¦,ğ±n){\boldsymbol{X}}_{n\times p} = ({\boldsymbol{x}}_{1},\ldots,{\boldsymbol{x}}_{n}), and ğš¯nÃ—q=(ğ›1,â€¦,ğ›n){\boldsymbol{\Theta}}_{n \times q} = ({\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{1},\ldots,{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}). If interest lies in the posterior distribution p(ğš¯,ğ›ƒ,ğšºâˆ£ğ˜,ğ—)p({\boldsymbol{\Theta}}, {\boldsymbol{\beta}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}\mid {\boldsymbol{Y}}, {\boldsymbol{X}}), then a Gibbs sampler can be used to cycle through the following conditional distributions:

ğ›iâˆ£ğ›ƒ,ğšº,ğ˜,ğ—âˆ¼indRxNorm(ğ²i,ğ•i,ğ±iâ€²ğ›ƒ,ğšº)ğ›ƒ,ğšºâˆ£ğš¯,ğ˜,ğ—âˆ¼MNIW(ğš²Ì‚,ğ›€Ì‚âˆ’1,ğš¿Ì‚,Î½Ì‚), \begin{aligned} {\boldsymbol{\mu}}_i \mid {\boldsymbol{\beta}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}, {\boldsymbol{Y}}, {\boldsymbol{X}}& \overset{\:\textrm{ind}\:}{\sim}\textrm{RxNorm}({\boldsymbol{y}}_i, {\boldsymbol{V}}_i, {\boldsymbol{x}}_i'{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}) \\ {\boldsymbol{\beta}}, {\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}\mid {\boldsymbol{\Theta}}, {\boldsymbol{Y}}, {\boldsymbol{X}}& \sim \textrm{MNIW}(\hat {\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}, \hat {\boldsymbol{\Omega}}^{-1}, \hat {\boldsymbol{\Psi}}, \hat \nu), \end{aligned}

where ğš²Ì‚\hat {\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}, ğ›€Ì‚\hat {\boldsymbol{\Omega}}, ğš¿Ì‚\hat {\boldsymbol{\Psi}}, and Î½Ì‚\hat \nu are obtained from the MNIW conjugate posterior formula with ğ˜â†ğš¯{\boldsymbol{Y}}\gets {\boldsymbol{\Theta}}.
